13531212121111211.content:
Stacy left the barn, heading to the west. while she walked, she brooded on what Amanda had said.

"Dead by thirty"? Sure, I've done some dumb stuff - that party was the least of it, only what my parents found out about. But every girl wants to have a little fun when she's my age. I would've straightened out eventually.

Stacy was so caught up in her reverie that she did not notice at first when two of her teeth jutted forward, becoming tusks. They only caught her attention when she reached up to scratch her face and her hand bumped against one of them.

She sighed and walked on. I guess it doesn't matter now, if I'm going to have to live out my life as an elephant.

Finally, she reached a river, where she stopped and thought about whether or not to try crossing it. Idly, she used her trunk to pull a leafy branch off of a tree and began devouring it. It was only after she'd eaten it that she realized what she'd done.

She looked at her reflection in the river. Her lower lip was now gray and wrinkly, and jutted out like an elephant's. Her teeth were broad and flat. Her ears were starting to change, too.

Stacy realized that she felt hot, so she leaned down and instinctively sucked some river water into her trunk and sprayed it over her back. She was still hungry, so she munch on some more tree branches. While she did so, her ears changed, and then her entire head became that of an elephant, albeit a very small one.

Should I cross the river? I better not. It might be deeper than it looks, and there's no one around to save me.

As turned back, she found that her head was so heavy that she could only stand upright for a brief period. She found it easier to walk on all fours - her arms seemed to have gotten longer. As she walked, her hands swelled up until her fingers disappeared except for the nails. By the time she got back to the barn, her arms had become an elephant's forelegs.

Stacy looked in the barn and saw Astrid. Her legs had changed, and the change was spreading up her lower torso - she now had a huge, flabby belly.

"Stacy, is that you?", she said.

Stacy found that...
13531212121111211.title: Stacy

135312121211112112.content:
Stacy tried to answer Astrid: "Yes, it's me!" is what she wanted, but instead a series of grunts and snorts came out.

Astrid...
135312121211112112.title: She understood Astrid, but could not speak

choices: No one had found anything interesting
1353121212111121121.content:
"Oh, OK.", said Astrid.

"You understood that?", grunted Stacy.

"Yeah, weird, isn't it? Did you find anything interesting?"

No, said Stacy. Just some pretty countryside. No sign of the others?

As if on cue, Anna, Belinda and Janet walked into the barn. Like Stacy, Janet and Anna's heads and arms had changed, and the change was spreading up Belinda's torso, although she was still able to walk bipedally.

The friends exchanged information, and...
1353121212111121121.title: Understood her

13531212121111211212.content:
The five friends exchanged information, and quickly realized that none of them had found anything, just seen some pretty countryside.

"I can't believe it", trumpeted Anna. "I can't believe that I'm never going to see my Mama or Maria ever again!"

Maria was Anna's thirteen year-old sister. Stacy stroked Anna with her trunk, trying to console her.

"I don't want to be a breeding animal!", said Janet.

"I don't want to be any kind of animal!", said Belinda. "And I'm not sitting still for this!"

With that, she stomped out of the barn. The others followed her, only to find themselves confronted with another huge spread of vegetables and greens.As before, they found themselves compelled to devour it.When they were finished, their transformations had progressed even further. Stacy found that only her legs and feet remained human. Interestingly, her breasts were only a little changed. She hadn't known much about elephant anatomy, but had half expected to have a row of teats, but it seemed that elephants only had two breasts, in roughly the same places on their bodies as human women did. Janet and Anna were similarly changed. As for Belinda and Astrid, only their arms, hands, necks and heads remained human. Astrid had dropped to all fours, but Belinda struggled to stay on her two feet.

Belinda shouted angrily: "This is it! I will not give in! I DEMAND TO SPEAK TO MOTHER NATURE! IF SHE'S GOING TO DO THIS TO ME, I DEMAND THE RIGHT TO TALK TO HER IN PERSON!"

The others waited with bated breath...
13531212121111211212.title: No one had found anything interesting

135312121211112112121.content: The person who appeared was...
135312121211112112121.title: ...And someone appeared!

choices: ..stay in the cage and wait until someone came.
...try and break out of the cage.
13533.content:
"Actually", said Amanda, "I work with parrots."

"Parrots?" said Stacy, interested despite herself.

"Yes. I've even brought a sample of the sort of cage I like to keep them in. Take a look", said Amanda, pointing behind Stacy. Stacy turned and then jumped back, startled. Behind her was a large metal bird cage, nearly five feet high.*

"Where did that come from? That wasn't here a minute ago!"

"I told you, dear. I just brought it."

Stacy looked at Amanda sharply, suspecting that the older woman was mocking her, then turned her attention to the cage. Stacy bent over in front of the cage and pulled the door open. As she looked at the cage, it seemed to start getting bigger and bigger. Her clothing began to feel looser and looser - when her pants suddenly fell down she realized that the cage wasn't getting bigger, she was getting smaller! The shrinking stopped when she was one foot high. She tried holding her shirt to cover herself, but it was now difficult to keep a grip on it. Even as she started to speak, she felt a powerful wind lifting her up, and blowing her into the cage! When the wind died away, she found herself stark naked, and precariously balanced on the perch in the cage. She turned just in time to see the cage door slam shut and lock itself behind her. She gasped as her feet began to change into those of a bird, steadying her balance as they curled around the perch. Grey feathers began to spread over her body as the change moved up her legs. Her arms re-shaped themselves into wings, and then the change completed itself as her face pushed forward into a beak. She was now a fine specimen of an African Grey parrot!

"Oh, my God", she said, "what's happening to me?"

"I should think that was obvious, Stacy", said Amanda. "I've turned you into a parrot."

"What? You did this? How? Why?"

"'How' was by magic. 'Why' is that you're easier to handle this way."

""Magic'? What are you, some kind of a witch?"

"Precisely!"

"But witches aren't real!"

"I don't think you're in a position to argue that point, my dear."

Stacy stopped to think about this for awhile, then she spoke again.

"Look, you can't leave me like this! Please, I'll behave, I'll be as good as gold!"

"Sorry, Stacy, but from what your parents have told me, your word hasn't always been good in the past."

"Maybe, but when my parents hear you turned me into a parrot..."

"Stacy, you parents already know. They hired me to do just this."

Stacy was stunned by this.

"They'll miss me at school..."

"The school's been told that your parents changed their plans at the last minute and took you with them."

"But I told my friends..."

"If any of your friends come by, I'll deal with them. If they get too nosy, maybe you'll have company in that cage."

Amanda stood up.

"Now listen carefully, Stacy, this is important. If you behave yourself, I'll leave the TV on for you, on whatever channel you like. If you don't behave - well then, you can amuse yourself reading the newspaper at the bottom of your cage. Now, from time to time, I'll have to open the cage to change your food and water and so on. If you leave that cage before I change you back, the change becomes permanent. Even I wouldn't be able to change you back then. So - no funny business. Just try to make the best of things, and the week will go by smoothly. Consider it a learning experience. Anyway, look on the bright side, I could have changed you into a bird that couldn't speak."


Stacy thought about this for awhile, then spoke once more.

"If you're such a powerful witch, why are you working as a babysitter? Surely you don't need the money?"

"Oh, I'm not being paid in money. Frankly, you'll sleep better at night not knowing what your parents are paying me."

Amanda picked up Stacy's clothes from the floor, folded them, and held them under one arm. With her free hand, she picked up the remote..

"So, what would you like to watch?"

Stacy sulkily watched her favorite shows that night, resisting Amanda's attempts at conversation. She fell asleep early, but woke in darkness to the sound of Amanda's voice from the other room.

"Hello? Oh, it's you. What? No, I can't. I can't, I'm doing a job. No, I mean it. What? He asked for me personally? I suppose I'll have to, then. I don't like it, though, it's really skirting close to breaking a contract. I will not be staying long. Alright, goodbye, I'll see you there.

Amanda came into the living room and faced Stacy's cage.

"Stacy, something's come up, and I have go out for awhile. I should be back in a few hours. You should be fine. Just you remember, though - if anyone comes around, you stay good and quiet if you ever want to be human again."

With that, she replenished Stacy's food and water, and left the house.

Amanda watched TV for awhile, then fluttered around the cage for awhile. Maybe it was of the spell, but she had figured out flight fairly quickly. She really didn't like being caged, and TV got boring eventually. She thought of the hamster she'd had as a little girl. She wondered what its life had been like. Well, she'd never keep an animal in a cage again, that was for sure. When nightfall came with no sign of Amanda, Stacy began to wonder where she was. When morning came with still no sign of Amanda, Stacy began to be really worried. She'd eaten all of the food she'd been left, and she was starting to get really hungry. What was worse was that Amanda had left the bag of Parrot Chow out on the kitchen counter right where Stacy could see it. She'd never imagined that the day would ever come when bird food would seem so appetizing to her, but that day was here!

The capper came when the local morning news broadcast reported that the badly-burned body of a middle-aged woman had been found in the park several miles from Stacy's home. The woman had been carrying no ID. The police's only clue was a ring the woman had been wearing which jad been engraved with the letter "A" in Gothic script.

A thrill of fear ran through Stacy. Was the dead woman Amanda? That would explain why she hadn't come back. If it was Amanda, what was going to happen to her? She was out of food and her water was running low. Her parents weren't due back for several days yet. If Amanda never came back, Stacy would starve to death in the cage. Should she try to break out of the cage? She remembered what Amanda had said about the change being permanent if she left the cage without permission. Was that a bluff to get her to behave?

Stacy decided she had two options:

On the one hand, she could stay in the cage and hope that someone would come by and feed her. Either Amanda would turn out to be delayed and not dead, or she could wait for someone to come to the house and try her best to get their attention and get them to feed her. If Amanda never came back, then her parents could just find another witch to change her back to normal.

On the other hand, she could try to break out and get some food and water, and maybe even try to get help somehow. The business about the change being permanent could well have been a lie, and anyway, life as a parrot beat death in a cage! At least parrots lived a long time!

Stacy thought it over awhile, and then decided to...


*Something like this: http://www.birdscomfort.com/macaw_parrot...
13533.title: Other

choices: ...Amanda was tellig the truth. You will be a parrot for sthe rest of your life.
"...I believe there's a chance that you could be restored to normal."
135332.content:
After thinking about it a little longer, Stacy decided to break out of the cage. She was getting hungrier and hungrier, and there was still no sign of Amanda coming back or of anyone coming by the house. She would just have to take the chance that Amanda was bluffing about the spell being permanent. Stacy flew over to the cage door, clinging to the cage with one foot, and examining the lock with the other. Stacy realized that she was in luck - Amanda had left in a hurry, and hadn't locked the cage door properly. Even so, it took her nearly half an hour to get the cage door open.

Once she had done so, she paused. This was the moment of truth. If Amanda had been telling the truth, then if Stacy left the cage now, she would be stuck as a parrot forever.

"I've come this far", she thought. "I may as well go all the way."

As she flew out of the cage, Stacy felt a tingling sensation all over her body. Was it the spell becoming permanent? Or was it maybe an "alarm" of sorts, to let Amanda know that she had left the cage. Well, it was too late to worry about it now. She flow over to where Amanda had left the bag of Parrot Chow and managed to get it open. Stacy helped herself to a mouthful - she'd never imagined that bird feed could taste so good. Then she flew over to the sink and managed to turn on the faucet to get some cold water flowing so she could have a drink.

Once she was sated, she decided to fly around the house. She flew around all of the rooms she could get into - if a room's door was closed, she couldn't open it. Everything seemed in order in all of the rooms she could get into. Finally, she went to her own room. The clothes she had been wearing when Amanda changed her were carefuuly folded and were lying on the bed. It made her sad to think that she might never wear clothes again. She noticed that her bedroom window was open. That was good - she could get out of the house if she had to. She was sure that she could tear through the screen with her beak, if she had to.

Stacy flew back into the living room and perched on the back of the couch, facing the TV. Enough time had passed that the noon news was about to come on. Stacy watched as the newscaster reported that police were no closer to establishing the identity of the burned woman. She thought about what to do next. It occurred to her that she ought to be able to use the phone to call someone. She flew over to the phone and managed to knock the handset loose from its base. She would be able to dial by peckign the appropriate buttons with her beak. But who should she call? The police? What could she tell them? "Help, a witch has turned me into a parrot"? No, they'd just think she was a kid pranking them. She'd have to claim that there was a medical emergency or something, and then try to explain it to them when they came. But would they believe her even then, or would they just think that she was someone's well-trained pet? And if they did believe her, what could they do for her? She might end up in a lab somewhere, or worse, a zoo!

It occurred to her that it would be lunchtime at school right now. She could call one of her friends without worrying about getting them in trouble with a teacher. Who to call? It had to be someone smart and open-minded, and who wouldn't be easily freaked out. Stacy thought about all of her friends and decided to call Maria Yoshino. She wasn't Stacy's best friend, but they were still good buddies, and Maria was very smart and flexible. If any one of her friends could help her figure out what to do, it would be Maria. Stacy flew to her room and got her address book out of her jacket pocket. She memorized Maria's number and flew back to the phone. With a little difficulty, she dialed Maria's cell phone. Maria answered on the second ring

"Hello?"

"Hi, Maria, it's Stacy."

"Stacy? I thought you went away with your parents?"

"No, I'm at home."

"Stacy, are you OK? You sound a little funny."

"Yeah, I'm not myself today. Listen, Maria, could I ask you a huge favor?"

"What is it?

"Could you come by my house after school? I've got kind of an unusual situation going on here, and I need some help figuring out what to do."

"Sure, what's going on?"

"I'd really rather not say until you get here. It'll be kind of obvious why then."

"OK, I guess I can do that. I should be able to get there by around 4:00."

"Thanks, M, I really appreciate it. Oh, and do me a favor - when you get here, don't come to the front door,. come around to my bedroom window, instead. The reason why will be obvious for that, too."

Stacy swore that she could hear Maria's eyebrows raise at that.

"OK, Stace, I'll do that."

"Oh, and one last thing, Maria. Please, please, PLEASE, don't tell ANYONE that you talked to me today."

"OK, Mystery Girl, but this better be good."

"Oh, it will, be, it will be. Thanks again, M!"

"Bye, Stace, I'll see you later."

Stacy hung up the phone and managed to work it back on to its base. She passed the next few hours wathcing TV. At 3:45, she flew into her bedroom and perched on the windowsill. Maria appeared right outside the window at 4:00. She was an attractive girl of Japanese ancestry. She wore rimless glasses and was dressed plainly but presentably. Maria looked up and saw Stacy. She gave the parrot a penetrating stare.

"Hello, little bird. Is Stacy in there somewhere?"

Stacy decided to go with the direct approach.

"Hello, Maria. I'm Stacy. The 'little bird' is me. A witch turned me into a parro.t"

To Stacy's surprise, Maria seemed to take this in stride.

"I thought it was you", said Maria. "I think I'd better come in there, don''t you?"

"I'd appreciate that", said Stacy. "I think if you push it, you should be able to open the screen enough to squeeze in."

"That won't be necessary", said Maria.

To Stacy's astonishment, Maria began to blur and then dissipate into a nearly invisible white mist, which flowed through the window screen and into Stacy's bedroom and re-shpaed itself into another African Grey parrot, perched on the windowsill next to Stacy.

"You see, Stace", the parrot said, "I'm a witch, too!"

"Maria? What's going on?"

"Let's get away from this window", said Maria, "We don't want anyone seeing us."

The two flew down to the living room and perched on the couch. Maria used the remote to turn off the TV. Stacy looked at ther friend.

"I can't believe you're a witch! You! Miss 'Scientific Skeptic!' You always say that magic is nonsense!"

"Most of what gets called 'magic' is nonsense. Any witch worth her salt is fairly skeptical of most so-called 'supernatural' stuff."

"Are there alot of you witches around?"

"Not that many real witches. Now tell me what happened to you."

Stacy told Maria the whole story, answering every question her friend had as best she could. As she wrapped up, she asked Maria the question that was uppermost in her mind.

"Was it true what Amanda said? Am I stuck as a parrot permanently?"

Maria looked thoughtful.

"Well, spells like that do exist, though it would be beyond my current power level. It's an awfully extreme spell to use for a simple babysitting job, though. I'm going to scan you, but I'll have to resume my normal form to do it. Don't worry, the scan won't hurt."

Maria flew off of the couch, then misted out and re-formed as her usual self. She began to mutter in a language that was already ancient in the time of Yamato Takeru, and her eyes began to glow green. Suddenly, twin beams of verdant light shot forth from her eyes, transfixing Stacy. There was no pain, but Stacy couldn't move. Abruptly, the light stopped. Maria's expression was unreadable as she spoke.

"Stacy...
135332.title: ...try and break out of the cage.

1353321.content:
"Stacy, Amanda was telling the truth. You will be a parrot for the rest of your life."

"Oh, God", said Stacy. "What am I going to do?"

Maria gave her friend a moment to compose herself, then spoke again.

"Let me call my mother. She knows alot of things that I don't."

Maria took out her cellphone and spoke again in the ancient language she had used before. After a brief conversation, she hung up and turned back to Stacy.

"My mom wants to have a look at you, do you mind coming over to our house?"

"No. Does she think there's any hope?"

"That's what she wants to find out."

Maria went around the house, checking to see that everything was in order. She checked the rooms that Stacy hadn't been able to get into previously, but didn't find anything unusual. Amanda hadn't left anything in the house except the birdcage and the Parrot Chow. Maria stuck this last into her backpack, then transformed herself into a robin.

"I'm going to cast an illusion spell to make you look like a robin, too. People will be less likely to notice us that way."

When this was done, the pair flew up to Stacy's room, where Maria "misted" them through the window screen. When they re-formed outside, she caused the window to shut and lock. The two then flew to Maria's house, stopping from time to time to perch on rooftops or tree branches. Stacy found the experience of flying around outside to be overwhelming. There were so many new sensations, and even her familiar neighborhood looked different when seen from above. Eventually, they came to Maria's house and flew in through the kitchen window, which Maria's mother had left open. Once they were inside, Maria resumed her human form and dispersed the illusion around Stacy.

Stacy alit on the kitchen table and looked at Maria's mother. Anna Yoshino was a striking woman, apparently in early middle age. There was no doubt that she was Maria's mother. After introducing herself, she scanned Stacy as Maria had. When she spoke to Stacy, her expression was as unreadable as Maria's had been.

"Stacy, I'm afraid that Maria was correct. The spell that was used on you is permanent, and I don't know of any way to break it. I flatter myself that that's saying alot."

"Is Amanda that powerful?" asked Stacy.

"I don't know Amanda," said Anna, "but I have heard of her, and she is said to be quite powerful. However, with spells like this, sheer raw power isn't everything. Some things have to be finessed. Enough raw power to break a spell like this would also be enough power to incinerate you, which would be contrary to our purposes."

"So I'm definitely stuck as a parrot?"

"I'm afraid so. About the only good thing about this is that you're now immune to any further transformations. No one will ever be able to transform you into anything else. I'm sure that isn't much consolation right now, however."

"What am I going to do?"

"Well", said Anna, "frankly, I'm quite concerned about this whole situation. We need to find out what happened to Amanda, and why your parents hired her to babysit you. It's bizarre - it's like hiring a brain surgeon to deal with a paper cut, or hiring Picasso to whitewash your fence. It's overkill. There's more going on here, and I want to know what it is."

"What do you think we should do?"

"The first thing I want to find out is whether the woman in the morgue is Amanda or not."

"How do we do that?"

"We need to get to the morgue and see the body they have there. Maria or I would be able to tell if she was a witch or not. Stacy, I'm afraid you'll have to go along, so that if she is a witch, we can test whether she was the one who put the spell on you."

"When will we do it?"

"We'll wait until tonight - the fewer the number of people around, the better."

Stacy spent the next few hours talking to Maria and Anna, going over everything she remembered about what Amanda had said to her. Later, she dozed for awhile. At midnight, Anna woke Stacy and Maria, and took them out to her car. She drove them to the morgue where the police were keeping the body. Parking nearby, she rendered the three of them invisible to everyone except themselves. Quietly they entered the building and went to the room where the body was. There was only one attendant present. Anna wordlessly placed him in a trance. Maria and Stacy looked away as Anna uncovered the body. She placed one hand on the body and one hand on Stacy and scanned the body. Then she re-covered it and released the attendant. Silently they returned to the car, where Anna made them all visible again.

"What do you think, Mom?" asked Maria.

"Let's wait until we get back to the house."

When they got back to the Yoshinos' home, Anna and Maria sat down on two easy chairs in the living room. Anna motioned Stacy to perch on the chair behind Maria.

Anna sighed, and said, "I scanned thoroughly, and I'm quite sure of the results."
1353321.title: ...Amanda was telling the truth."

choices: "...we'd better go and see them now."
13533211.content:
The room was quiet for a moment, before Stacy finally spoke.

"So, she's dead. What could kill a witch like her?"

"Even a high-ranking witch isn't indestructible. In fact, most of the things that would kill a mundane would kill one of us if we were careless or taken by surprise. I once knew a powerful witch that was killed by a cross-town bus."

"So, what will you do? Are there 'witch police' that you report this sort of thing to?"

"There are..'authorities'.. that one can contact if absolutely necessary, but it's generally not in anyone's interest to invoke them lightly. Ordinarily, since I am neither friend nor family to Amanda, I would keep my nose out of this business. However, I want to find out whether what happened to Amanda has anything to do with you. I prefer to be forewarned if who or whatever did for Amanda is going to come after you."

A thrill of fear went through Stacy - she hadn't thought of anything like that! Stacy hung her head.

"Thank you very much for everything you've done for me, Mrs. Yoshino. I really appreciate it."


"Stacy, you're a friend of my daughter's and you came to her for help. As far as I'm concerned, that puts you under her - and therefore my - protection."

Stacy thanked the older woman again. She knew on some level that she was going to owe a huge debt to the Yoshinos.

"So, Mom", said Maria, what do we do now?"

"We need to find out what happened to Amanda. The first thing we need to do is go back to Amanda's house, it will be easier to follow her 'trail' from there."

The trio drove back over to Stacy's house. Anna magicked the front door open and they went inside.

"Now tell me, Stacy," she said, "where did you see Amanda last?"

Stacy perched on top of the cage.

"I was in here."

"I see. I'm going to try and call up the images of what happened here a few days ago, and see if we can pick up Amanda's trail that way."

"You can see into the past?"

"To an extent. Hush now."

Anna began to mutter a spell, making passes with her arms at the same time. Stacy's vision blurred for a moment, then cleared again. She was watching herself two days ago! The prespective shifted from to the guest room where Amanda was staying. She watched as Amanda answered her cellphone. It was the same conversation, only now they could hear both sides of it:

"Hello?"

"Hello, Amanda."

"Oh, it's you."

"Listen, you've to meet me at the Blue Coyotl right away! Something really big is brewing!"

" What? No, I can't."

"You have to, this is big - and potentially very profitable."

" I can't, I'm doing a job."

"A job? you aren't serious!"

" No, I mean it."

"You have to! We need someone good and Alberich asked for you personally!"

"What? He asked for me personally?"

"Yup."

" I suppose I'll have to, then."

"Wonderful!"

"I don't like it, though, it's really skirting close to breaking a contract. I will not be staying long."

"Fine, fine. Come right now, and we'll have you back there in two, three hours tops. Your client won't even miss you "

"Alright, goodbye, I'll see you there."

"Great! Thanks, Amanda, you won''t regret it!"

Stacy watched as Amanda came out and told her she was leaving, and gave her the warning about leaving the cage. The scene faded and Anna began to speak.

"Now that was interesting." She began muttering a new incantation.

Stacy whispered to Maria, "What do you make of that?"

"It looks as though some firend of hers called her away to work another job. It's very bad form to leave one job to go do another. Witches take contracts very seriously - more seriously even than mundanes do. Really, you're not supposed to break a contract for anything short of death. Sometimes even death - even your own death isn't considered a valid excuse. An ethical witch just wouldn't do it."

"That's right, dear", interjected Anna. " But I am increasingly convinced that Amanda was not an ethical witch."

"What's the Blue Coyotl?" asked Stacy.

"It's a popular meeting place for a certain type of witch. Something like what a dive bar would be for mundanes, but if anything, even sleazier than most dives. The fact that Amanda knew the place and would readily go meet someone there says alot about her."

"That's amazing! I neve rknew there was anything in our town!"

"You can access it from our town, but it's not actually in our town, strictly speaking. Hush now, I'm going to try and follow Amanda's "trail" to see what she did when she left here."

Stacy watched as she saw a projection of Amanda leaving her house and transforming herself into a parrot, flying towards the park where her body was eventually found. When she got there, she landed next to a tree, resuming human form. She knocked on the tree, and it opened up like a door. Inside was something like a tavern out of a ren-fest, only empty and dark. It had the look of a room that had been evacuated in a hurry. Amanda stepeed inside and the portal closed behind her. She looked around, confused.

"Arachne? Are you here? Why is this place empty? Where in Hell are you?" Amanda whirled as a voice came form behind her.

"In the circle reserved for traitors, no doubt, where you shall shortly join her!"

The speaker was a tall, beautiful woman with long blonde hair and icy blue eyes. She wore shimmering blue robes embroidered with intricate designs. Stacy had always liked boys (for all that her boy-chasing days were almost certainly over), but she could well imagine falling in love with this woman.

"Vieno!" shouted Amanda.

"So, you remember the name of she whom you robbed!"

"No! It wasn't me! It was Arachne's idea!"

"Liar! Arachne would not have had the nerve or the wit to concoct such a scheme! But fear not! She has paid for her part in your robbery. She lived just long enough to sell your location to me before I paid her in the same kind of 'gold' I am about to pay you!"

Vieno raised her hands and they began to glow with a pulsing golden light.

"No!" cried, Amanda, sobbing. "Please! Have mercy!"

"NEVER!" Stacy, Maria and Anna looked away as twin bolts of golden fire shot from Vieno's hands, enveloping Amanda. Fortunately for their sanity,Amanda's screams did not last long. A portal opened below her remains, dropping them down into the park. Vieno turned and seemed to be looking right at the three watchers. Vieno spoke.

"And as for you, who watch from the future..."

Stacy was horrified: "She can SEE us, she can SEE us, she can SEE!"

"Yes", said Vieno. "I can see you, little bird. But fear not, for I have no quarrel with you, who have also suffered from Amanda's venality. Alas, even I cannot undo what she has done to you. But be of stout heart. If you can keep your nerve, there may yet be happiness in your future. You have my blesssing, child. For now, farewell!"

With that, the projection vanished, and the three once again saw Stacy's living room around them. They sat very still, for even Anna was shaken. After a minute, Anna went to the refrigerator and took one of Stacy's dad's beers out, opened it up, and took a long gulp.

"Well", said Anna, "I've seen all sorts of things in my life, but that takes the cake. To think that a witch lived who was stupid enough to rob Vieno!"

"Who was she, Mom?" asked Maria.

"Vieno! One of the Ancient Elders! One of the thirteen most powerful witches alive! Merciful Mother, what was Amanda thinking? Robbing Vieno is a bit like robbing an irritable H-Bomb! And you, Stacy! She gave you her blessing! Really, you ought to go out and play the lottery tonight or something! Talk about a favorable omen."

As Anna downed the rest of her beer, Stacy spoke:

"So, what do we do now?"

Anna set down her beer bottle and looked thoughtful.

"The next thing I want to do is have a serious talk with your parents. When did you say they were coming back from Paris?"

"Sunday evening."

"I see. Well then, ...
13533211.title: "It was Amanda."

135332111.content:
"In the meantime, you'd better stay with us, Stacy. It's getting quite late, let's get home and get some rest."

And so they drove back to the Yoshino home. Maria set up a sleeping area for Stacy in her room. They both fell asleep very quickly.

In the morning, Maria went off to school, promising to see Stacy later. After she had gone, Anna sat down at the kitchen table, sipping a cup of coffee. Stacy spoke to her.

"Ma'am, what do you think Amanda meant when she said I'd sleep better not knowing how my parents paid her?"

"Well, as you can imagine, a powerful witch doesn't really have to worry much about money as such. It's easy enough to magick up all the cash you need if you're so minded. However, there are things which cannot be purchased with money or treasure or what have you. For example, certain types of spells require certain types of...energies...which can only be obtained through, shall we say, manipulation of the human life force. It's possible that your parents gave her 'access' to their bodies and/or souls in return for looking after you for a few days."

Stacy felt ill.

"Oh, my God! You don't mean they did that with Amanda?"

"Maybe not that exactly, but I'm afraid it would have been something at least that 'intimate'."

"But why would they do something like that?"

Anna looked thoughtful.

"Tell me, Stacy, what has your relationship been like with your parents?"

"They've always been OK. I mean they're, well... parents... you know? They have been kind of uptight ever since they went away the last time, and I threw that party."

"'Uptight'...hmmm..." said Anna. "Setting aside the busienss with the party, would you say they'vegotten alot stricer even before that?"

"A little, I suppose. They really haven't liked me being around boys at all."

"Tell me, why did they go to Paris?"

"They wanted to get away for awhile, they said", replied Stacy.

"So, it wasn't a business trip?"

"No."

"Stacy, I'm afraid we're going to have to discuss something a little personal, here. When I scanned you before, I could tell that you are still a virgin."

"What's that got to do with anything?"

"Listen, there's alot of potential magickal energy of a unique type tied up in a girl's virginity. Properly released, it can be used to achieve powerful effects that are very difficult to create any other way. That's why you hear so much about 'virgin sacrifices'. It's also why it's vitally important that a girl be very careful as to when and how and to whom she 'gives it up'. Not for prudish or Puritan reasons, but because it can be devastating if that energy is misused. Also, once the deed is done, that energy is gone forever. Tell me, Stacy, was there never a boy that tempted you?"

"Well, there was a guy that I came close to doing it with. He was at the party that night - it might have even happened then and there, but my parents came home unexpectedly, and somehow it was never the same with him again after that. Say, do you think that that's what this is alll about? My parents wanted to make sure this energy didn't get used up?"

"Maybe. We'll know more when we talk to them."

And so Stacy spent the next few days with the Yoshinos. She had a pretty good time, considering the circumstances. When Sunday afternoon came along, the three of them went over to Stacy's house.They checked the house out, but everything seemed fine there. Anna magicked the bird cage away and then spoke to Stacy.

"I think it best if we try to catch your parents by surprise. If they come home and find us here like this, they'll know something's wrong right away and be on their guard. So, we're going to disguise ourselves. Stacy, I'm going to render you invisible to everyone but the three of us. Maria, I want you to take on Stacy's human form, and I will take on Amanda's form."

With that, Anna muttered and gestured. Her body blurred and re-formed as the exact duplicate of Amanda. Stacy winced a little when she saw Maria take her old form, the one she would never to wear again. She felt a slight tingling as Annna made her invisible.

They passed the time amiably, waiting. Stacy's parents had expected to be home between 6:00 and 7:00 p.m. Maria checked on-line and verified that their flight had arrived on schedule. However, 6:00 anmd then 7:00 and then 8:00 came and went with no sign of them. When 9:00 came with no result, Anna frowned and said, "Hmm, I wonder..."

Before she could finish...
135332111.title: ...we'll wait until they come back."

1353321112.content:
Anna (as Amanda) looked through the keyhole of the front door. It was Stacy's parents. She scanned them magically. There were no obvious spells or enchantments on them, but there was something definitely "off" about them, though she couldn't say exactly what. Still, she could think of no reason not to let them in, so she opened the door.

"Hello, George, Vera", she said. "How was your trip?"

"Sorry we're late", said George. "Traffic was a little heavier than we'd expected." He and Vera were both carrying two heavy bags.

"Stacy, help your parents with their luggage", said Anna.

"Sure", siad Maria (as Stacy), but her father waved her away. Insread, her parents simply let the bags drop onto the floor.

Anna scanned them again. She had feared some trap, but she could detect none. It was a calculated risk, but she decided to make her move. She cast a spell entrancing Stacy's parents, commanding them to go sit on the couch. She dropped her disguise and rendered Stacy visible. She nodded to Maria, wog also dropped her disguise.

"What did you do to them?" asked Stacy, flying around her parents' heads.

"I've just put them into a trance. They'll have to answer any questions truthfully and completely now." she turned to George and Vera.

"George, Vera, why did you hire Amanda to babysit Stacy?"

George replied: "We needed to make sure that she remained a virgin."

"Why was that so important?"

Vera spoke: "She was promised."

"'Promised'?" said Anna. "Promised to who?"

"Who Dwells Outside", said George.

Anna gasped. "You promised your daughter to that! Why? In the name of She-Who-Invites, why?"

"When we were young", said Vera. "We both worked at an accounting firm. We met at a company function, and began dating. We discovered that we each had an interest in black magic and embezzlement."

George took up the story. " We came up with a scheme to rob the company blind and to use magic to cover our tracks. We stole the money but our magic failed. One of our colleagues figured out where we were doing. She was gathering evidence against us to take to our boss. We found out that she knew. We were desperate. We managed to get her alone and drug her. We took her to our home, and then tried to decide what to do.with her. Even if we killed her and got away with it, it would only be a matter of time before we were caught."

Vera continued. "We searched all of the magickal books we had. I found the name of Who Dwells Outside in an old book. It gave its true name, T -"

"Don't say it!" interjected Anna.

Vera resumed her narrative. "We performed the ritual of summoning, slitting her throat as an offering to Who Dwells Outside."

"You killed her?" said Stacy.

"Yes, it was us or her."

Stacy reeled inside. Her parents were crooks and killers! Being turned into a parrot was less of a shock than this!

"Is what they're saying real?" she said.

"They can't lie right now", said Anna. "So it must be true."

"Who or what is 'Who Dwells Outside'?" asked Stacy.

"A ancient, powerful creature that originates outside of our reality. It delights in causing pain and chaos. Anyone who deals with it ends up regretting it. The worst part is, your parents killed that poor woman just to summon him. They needn't have bothered - just speaking his name summons him."

"And they promised me to him? What does that even mean?"

Anna looked at Stacy sadly. "Remember what we were saying earlier about a girl's viginity?"

"Oh. my God! But why?"

George began to speak again. "Who Dwelled Outside helped us. Covered up our tracks at the company. Cleaned up the woman's body. Helped set us up in a new life on the other side of the country. Even taught us a little real magic."

"And in return for this?" asked Anna.

"We were to turn over our daughter, pure and intact, when he demanded her."

Vera added, "At the time I didn;t even know that I was pregnant, let alone that it would be a girl. But Who Dwells Outside knew."

Stacy, squawked at her parents "And you were to turn me over for that? This can't be real! God, I feel like I don't even know you!"

Ann tried her best to comfort Stacy. Inwardly,she wondered whether the girl's parents were sociopaths. It was a wonder that Stacy had turned out as well as she did.

"So, what sdo we do now, Mom?" asked Maria.

"We get out of here and get home before Who Dwells Outside arrives."

A voice spoke from behind them. "A bit late for that, I'm afraid."

Anna, Maria and Stacy spun around. A well-dressed but somewhat dumpy-looking middle-aged man stood in the doorway. Completely ordinary-looking, apart from his glowing red eyes.

"W-who are you?" asked Stacy.

"I am T'aksa'ntek - Who Dwells Outside", the man said.

"That's him?" said Maria.

The man smiled. "Perhaps you were expecting something a little more like Cthulhu, or something similarly Lovecraftian? I can do that, but I don't usually. Dear old Howard, he remains the only mortal ever to creep me out. As improbable as it may seem, I sometimes think that he must have gone somewhere even I've never been. Anyway. To business. I've come to collect my fee. I see that she's a bird now. That halfwit Amanda! Really, I warned those two that she was dangerous, but they wouldn't listen! But, that's as may be. Surrender the girl to me, and I'll leave you in peace. You can do what you like with her parents. A witch of your caliber ought to be able to use them for ingredients in something or other."

"This girl", said Anna, "is under my protection."

"And who will protect you, my dear? Or your daughter?"

Without warning, he shot a beam of red light straight at Anna. She erected a shield. It held, but she began to sweat almost instantly. Maria moved to bolster her mother, but Anna shook her head.

"Maria! Take Stacy and get out of here! You know where to go! I can hold him long a little while, but not long!"

Hearing this, Who Dwells Outside snarled and redoubled his efforts. Anna gaped, but her shield held.

Maria spoke.. "Mom, I - !"

Go!"

Maria nodded, and turned herself into a bird. She flew towards the front door.

"Stacy, come on!"

Stacy hesitated. "But we can't just abandon your mom!"

"We can't help her! Come on!" Maria flew out the door without looking back.

Stacy hesitated, and...
1353321112.title: ...the doorbell rang!

choices: "Can't  we find a less dangerous way?"
13533211121.content:
Stacy flew swiftly after Maria. She flew faster than she had before. She suspected that Maria might be pulling her along in a sort of magical slipstream. Soon enough they arrived at the Yoshino home. Maria resumed human form and let them in the front door.

"Is your house a safe place to be?" asked Stacy. "Won't he be able to follow us here?"

"My Mom's been living in this house for a hundred and fifty years. In that time, she's put alot of time and effort into its defenses. Even Who Dwells Outside would think twice before trying to force its way in here. It might get in eventually, but it would use up enough energy doing so that even I would have a good chance of beating him."

"This house is a hundred fifty years old? It doesn't look much more than forty!"

"My mother's good at illusions. Now, come on, we've got to get down to the basement."

As they walked through the living room, the TV popped on. Who Dwells Outside appeared on the screen. It was still in the living room of Stacy's house.

"Hello, Maria", said T'aksa'ntek. "I see you've run to ground. Smart move. It would certainly take more time and effort than I want to spend to come in there after you. However, I do believe I have a way to lure you here. Come here, slave."

"Yes, Master", said Anna from "off-camera". She walked to T'aksa'ntek's side. Maria gasped. Her mother was hideously changed. Her legs were now capriform, her ears were pointed, and curling horns jutted from her forehead. The skin on her uncovered torso was dark red. The total effect was to make her look like the pop culture image of a she-devil. She draped her arms seductively around T'aksa'ntek's neck and smiled lasciviously. Only her eyes told a different story - Maria saw outrage and pain in her eyes. Maria shook with anger and fear.

"She's a very formidable witch, your mother", said Who Dwells Outside, "you should be proud. I was able to batter down her defenses and take control of her body, but as you can see, even now, her mind defies me. I expect it's going to take about another hour to break through her final defenses. Then she will be mine completely. I'll eat her soul and fill her body up with my will, making her my creature forever. So, you've got about that much time to surrender Stacy to me. I wouldn't take that long if I were you.This sort of thing can be pretty unpredictable."

The screen went blank. Stacy saw the anguish in Maria's eyes. She knew what she had to do.

"Maria", she said, "I'm so sorry for dragging you and your mother into this. Look, I haven't got much of a life left - I'm stuck as a parrot, and my parents are deranged jerks. Let me just turn myself over to Who Dwells Outside and get this over with."

"Shut up", said Maria angrily, with tears in her eyes. "It's not happening. My mother would disown me if I let it have you just to save her."

"Then what are we going to do?"

"We're going down into the basement." Maria led Stacy down into the basement. It looked like a normal basement, filled with the detritus of a normal American life. In the back, there was an ornate door built into the wall.

"This is my mother's 'inner sanctum'. I've never actually been in here. This is where she keeps private things, things she wouldn't share with anyone, not even me. She also keeps dangerous things in here. - powerful magickal objects. I am hopeful that there's something in here that we can use. You heard Mom say that I would know where to go. Well, this is where she meant."

Maria opened the door. The room looked like something out of an old Japanese inn. Various objects rested on shelves lining the walls. Stacy perched on Maria's shoulder as Maria looked at the various items. She fluttered into the air when Maria suddenly gasped and bent over to look at something on a bottom shelf.

"What is it?" Stacy asked.

"It's something that we could use that could give us a very good chance to defeat Who Dwells Outside."

"Well, let's use it, then."

"There's just one small problem," said Maria.

"What's that?"

"There would also be a very good chance that it could destroy us both."

Maria held out her hand in front of her so that Stacy could light on it, and the two could speak face-to-face.

"So", said Maria, "you game?"

Stacy looked at her, and said:
13533211121.title: ...flew out the door after Maria.

135332111211.content:
"What is it you found?" asked Stacy.

Maria held up what looked like a gold ring with a large red jewel set in it. "It's the Ring of Oolt-thoor. I never knew that my mother had anything like this. I've only seen it in the Encyclopedia Magica."

"What does it do?"

"It enables the wielder to use an opponent's energy against them. The only problem is that when it's used, there's kind of a backwash against the wielder. The more of your opponent's power you try to use against them, the more is directed back against you. Against an enemy like Who Dwells Outside, the backwash would almost certainly be enough to destroy me. An experienced witch like my mother would be able to re-route enough of the backwash energy that she could survive. I'm not really powerful enough. In a best case scenario, I might be able to do what you might call a "kamikaze" attack on Who Dwells Outside, but even then I wouldn't be guaranteed of beating it. I might be able to weaken it enough that my mother could break free and finish it off. There is a way you could help me with it, though."

"How?"

By becoming my fa'iit't'aarah."

"What's that?"

"There's no good English translation. The closest I could give you is something like 'animal-partner'."

"You mean, like a familiar?"

"Sort of", said Maria. "However it happened, you're a magickal animal, now. That means you now contain a fair amount of potential magickal energy. Add to that the fact that Vieno gave you her blessing. From a witch like her. that's more that just well-wishing. For awhile at least, the laws of probability will have shifted significantly in your favor. Put all that together, and it means that if you were my fa'iit't'aarah, I'd be able to tap enough additional magickal energy that I'd stand a much better chance of beating Who Dwells Outside with incinerating myself."

"Then let's do it!" said Stacy.


"Wait, there's more I have to tell you first. This bond, it would be permanent, breakable only by the death of one or the other of us. Our life forces would be linked. If I die, you will die, too. If you die, I may survive, but from what I've been told, it's an extremely traumatic event for the witch it happens to. Also, the bond is very intimate, very deep."

"You make it sound like a marriage!" said Stacy.

"It's not like a marriage, but in some ways we'd be even closer than spouses would. In point of fact, if we do this, it'll most likely mean I'll never end up marrying. Most witches that take on a fa'iit't'aarah never do."

"You'd give that up?"

"To save my mother? Definitely. Anyway, there's no rule that says I couldn't take on consort or two over the years" said Maria, smirking. "For that matter, we could find you a nice boy parrot, if you felt that need."

Stacy would've blushed if she still could. Maria continued.

"Ordinarily, we'd spend about a year being tested for compatibility before the bond, but we haven't got time for that. One final thing - this would be a partnership, but it's not an equal partnership. I would be the senior partner. You would essentially be agreeing to enter my service. Now I assure you that I wouldn't treat you like a slave, but it's up to you to decide how much faith you have in me." Maria smiled. "I can promise you an exciting life, and it might last thousands of years if it outlasts the next hour."

"What will you do if I say no?" asked Stacy.

Maria smiled amiably. "Then I will go and fight Who Dwells Outside as best I can, win if possible, and 'die gloriously for Clan Yoshino' if I must."

"And if I do this, we can beat Who Dwells Outside?"

"I'll be honest - our chances will increase a great deal, but even then I can't guarantee success."

Stacy thought hard. This would be the biggest decision she'd ever made. It could also be the last decision she'd ever make, depending on how things went. She thought over her options, and looked Maria in the eyes for a minute. then she said:
135332111211.title: "Let's do it."

choices: ...Who Dwells Outside was waiting for them.
1353321112111.content:
"Thank you, Stacy", said Maria. "We'd better do this quickly." She began to undress. "Don't worry, I'm not getting frisky. I just have to be completely uncovered for the bonding. 'Nothing hidden', as the old books say. I should warn you - the experience will be pretty intense. a witch and her partner usually spend about a week recovering after the bonding. We'll have to do it in minutes. Ordinarily, there'd be a huge ritual with the highest ranking witch available officiating and every witch I've ever known who could make it in attendance, but that's all window dressing. In the end, it comes down to you and it it comes down to me."

Quickly, Maria outlined the ritual for Stacy. Then she stood up straight and looked as dignified as a naked girl with a parrot standing on her right hand could.

"Stacy, daughter of Vera, do you - freely and of your own will - agree to enter into my service as my fa'iit't'aarah?

"Maria, daughter of Anna, I do so agree."

"Then, so be it!"

Maria put her left hand on Stacy's head and spoke an incantation. For Stacy, it was as intense as Maria had said it would be. It was like a lightning bolt went through her. Suddenly, she was in Maria's mind, and Maria was in hers. She knew Maria like she'd never known anyone, and Maria knew her likewise. Knowing Maria as she now did, she felt with all her heart that she'd made the right choice. Maria staggered and then sat straight down on the floor. Stacy fluttered to the floor next to her.

After a minute, Maria began to dress herself. Then she put the ring on.

"Well, Stacy, are you ready to go?"

"Yes, 'Mistress'", said Stacy.

Maria smiled sadly. She knew that Stacy was joking, but she also knew that in a real way, she was her friend's mistress now. Before today, she hadn't even begun to think about whether she wanted to take on a fa'iit't'aarah or not. Now she had taken on an awesome, life-long responsbility after only a few minutes' consideration. Even to save her mother's life, it was a staggering thing to do. She set the reverie aside. Time was burning.

Maria and Stacy left Anna's 'inner sanctum'. Maria carefully locked the door. The two left the Yoshino home and flew over to Stacy's house. Maria opened the front door, and they went into the living room, and...
1353321112111.title: Yes!

13533211121111.content:
Who Dwells Outside stood right where he had been when they left. Anna was standing next to him, and Stacy's parents were still sitting on the couch, entranced.

"So, you've come back, have you?", it asked. Its eyes narrowed as it scanned them. "So, you've bonded, have you? And you think that will save you?"

"No, but but I think this just might," said Maria, raising he rright hand, so that Who Dwells Outside could see the ring she now wore.

"Interesting", it said. "But I wonder how far you would go to use it. Slave, defend me!"

Anna sprang between Who Dwells Outside and Maria. Maria looked into her mother's eyes. She could see that some small portion of her mother's will was still fighting on inside her mind. Maria directed a silent apology to her mother and then magickally swept her her out of the way, hurling her across the room and pinning her to the far wall.

Who Dwells Outside took advantage of this situation to launch an attack against Maria, but she was able to shield herself just in time. The house shook as their duel began in earnest. Waves of energy streamed around them both. Stacy felt power flowing from her to Maria. Each penetrated the other's shield. Maria's clothes caught fire and Stacy singed her feathers trying to beat the flames out.

"Let it go!" said Maria. "Keep your distance, I need you intact!" Maria struck back, causing T'aksa'ntek to grunt.

"Well done, my dear", it said. "No one's made me work this hard in centuries!"

For a long time, it seemed to Stacy that the fight was even, or perhaps even beginning to slide in Who Dwells Outside's favor. But then, Maria seemed to rally, and the tide began to turn. Suddenly, Stacy heard the voice of Who Dwells Outside in her head.

Stacy, I'm shielding these thoughts from Maria, this is between the two of us. I want to ask you, has it occurred to you that Maria has done the same thing to you that I intended to do? She used you to make herself stronger, to gain an advantage. Worse, she's enslaved you for life! I only intended to use you once, to take something that you just would have given to some boy eventually anyway! I wouldn't have needed you afterwards. Just a simple one-time thing - it could even have been pleasant! But even at worst, it would have been over quickly. But, you can still be free! I don't need your soul, especially. Deny your energy to Maria now, and when I've won, I'll transfer your soul into Maria's body, and her soul into yours. Once that's done, I'll re-shape Maria's body into a copy of your old one. I'll deal with Maria and Anna, and leave you here in peace. I'll even make your parents your slaves, so you can spend the rest of their lives making them sorry for selling you to me! Think it over, but be quick! This is your last chance to be human! This is your last chance to be free!


Anna thought over what Who Dwells Outside was offering - a chance to be free, to be herself again! Btu could she trust Who Dwells Outside? Could she buy her freedom at the price of selling out a friend? in the end, the marshalled her thoughts and sent the folliwng message back to it:
13533211121111.title: ...Who Dwells Outside was waiting for them.

choices: "With respect, ma'am, may I offer a suggestion of my own?"
135332111211112.content:
Stacy sent a strong refusal to Who Dwells Outside. In the end, she had faith in Maria and Anna. She let her power flow freely to Maria.

Enraged, Who Dwells Outside made one last push. Maria was wreathed in flame. Her clothes and hair burned off, but still she didn't falter. Her shield held and she returned the assault, pushing her opponent back. Who Dwells Outside began to cringe and beg for mercy

"Please! I can do things for you! I can make you even more powerful! I can make you the strongest witch this world has ever seen!"

Maria coldly replied, "No", and made one final effort. Screaming, Who Dwells Outside vanished in a puff of fire. Maria sank to her knees, smoke rising from her body. Stacy alit on the floor beside her.

"Did you kill it?" she asked.

"No", said Maria. "A thing like it can't be killed. But I have banished it from our world forever. It can never return here. That's as complete a victory as we could possibly have over a being like that. She looked down at Stacy. "I could never have done it without you, Stacy. Thank you so much. I know what it must have cost you to turn down what he offered you."

"You knew?"

"I knew. And it knew that I knew, but it wanted you to think I didn't. I let you think that I didn't know, because I wanted the decision to be yours. You had to choose loyalty to me freely, and you did."

Maria shrank herself to Stacy's size and hugged her friend. A voice came from across the room.

"Maria, daughter of Anna, your humble mother begs your assistance in freeing herself from this wall, where you, in your righteous anger, have seen fit to imprison her."

Maria looked at her mother. With the disappearance of Who Dwells Outside, her mother had resumed her normal form, but was still stuck to the wall. Since her mother was addressing her in the formal mode reserved for momentous occasions, Maria responded in kind.

"Anna, daughter of Noriko, your loving daughter is at your service, and apologizes for daring to lay hands upon your august person."

With that, she freed her mother, and the two women embraced.

"I'm so proud of you, Maria."

"I love you, Mom."

"And I love you, too, dear, always and forever."

Maria stepped back and grinned.

"Geez, Mom, you're all naked. Let me whip up something for you to wear."

Maria gestured, and Anna was clothed in a tee-shirt, blue jeans and sneakers, her hair done up in a pony tail.

Anna smirked and said:

"You're pretty bare yourself, my dear."

She gestured, and Maria was clad in a woman's business suit, her hair done in a severe-looking bun.

Anna looked at her daughter's hand.

"So, you used the Ring of Oolt-thoor. I wondered what you would choose from what I had in my 'sanctum'. I might have known that you'd choose the most powerful item in there."

Maria blushed, and made to offer the ring to her mother.

"Sorry, Mom, it seemd like my best choice at the time."

Anna forestalled her.

"Keep it. You've earned it. It belongs to the stronger witch."

"'The stronger witch'? Me?"

"Yes, you. You used an item of power to defeat and banish an elder being. You can't do that and remain unchanged. To use a video game analogy, in terms of raw magickal power, you've moved about ten levels ahead of me. I still have an advantage in knowledge and skill, but it will be my great pleasure to help you surpass me there as well."

Anna looked over at where Stacy was, perched on end table. Maria looked also, then stepped back and re-entered the formal mode.

"Honored mother, I beg leave to report that during the recent emergency, I took the step of taking on Stacy, daughter of Vera, as my fa'iit't'aarah. I beg your forgiveness for taking such a momentous step without first consulting you, but the circumstances at the time seemed to call for precipitous action."

Anna looked at her disapprovingly, but Stacy saw a twinkle in her eye.

"My daughter, given the nature of the situation, and your relative youth and inexperience, I am prepared to overlook your misdeeds just this once."

She could not contain her laughter long, and soon she and Maria were again hugging one another. Anna turned to Stacy, and held out her right hand.

"Stacy, will you please come over here?"

Stacy flew over and alit on Anna's hand.

"Stacy, I want to thank you for standing by and helping my daughter in what can only have been an extremely trying and traumatic situation. You've joined our family in a most unusual and unexpected way, but I welcome you, and hope that you will come to think of me as of a mother."

"Thank you, ma'am". said Stacy, touched.

Anna turned to George and Vera, who were still motionless on the couch.

"Now, as for them: I'm not the law, but I'm not of a mind to leave them unpunished. As for their crime of selling you to Who Dwells Outside, one could say they've already paid for it, having lost both their daughter and whatever reward Who Dwells Outside was going to give them. However, there is the crime of murder, for which they have not been punished. Stacy, I have an idea of how best to punish them. Will you accept my guidance on this?

Stacy thought about it, and said:
135332111211112.title: No!

choices: Now follow the story of Maria and Stacy in training!
Now flash forward to the future, sometime after the training is complete!
1353321112111121.content:
Anna, Maria and Stacy left the house, with George and Vera following them. Stacy couldn't help noticing that, even allowing for the teenager's clothes that Maria had dressed her in, Anna looked hardly any older than Maria. Anna smiled when Stacy told her this.

"This is my normal appearance", she said. "You see, we witches age differently than mundanes do. Well, we age 'normally' until we're about eighteen to twenty. Then we begin to age very slowly - it varies from witch to witch. It should hit Maria soon. Get used to how she looks now, she probably won't look much different for a century or two."

"Doesn't that cause problems with people wondering why you never age?"

"Not really. Typically when I go out in public, I disguise myself to look more like whatever age I'm claiming at a given point in time. Eventually, when enough time passes, I just use my magic to establish a new identity for myself, and alter memories and records accordingly. I'm five hundred years old and I've llived in this town for the last hundred and fifty or so."

"Five hundred forty-three, Mother."

"Thank you, dear."

Anna drove them to a nearby forest.

"This looks like a nice place", she said. They walked from the car into the woods. It was dark, but Anna cast a spell that enabled them to see clearly. They found a clearing in the forest, and stopped. Anna had George and Vera stand a good distance apart from one another.

"George, son of Howard, and Vera, daughter of Eleanor, hear now your sentence, for the crime of murder."

"W-what are you going to do?" asked George.

"Fear not", said Anna, "I am no executioner. Your sentence is to be life imprisonment."

"What do you mean?" asked Vera.

"This!" said Anna, casting a spell. Stacy watched as her parents' clothing disappeared. For a moment, nothing else seemed to happen, but then Stacy noticed that their feet had turned a brownish-gray. Vera shrieked as she felt her toes and heels extending into roots. Bark appeared on their feet as they began to merge together. The change spread up their thighs as their legs began to merge together to form trunks. As the change moved up their torsos, their arms extended out as if of their own accord, transforming into branches. Leaves grew from what had been their fingers. Finally their heads, too, changed - they had become two smallish oak trees. Ana and Maria worked together to cast a second spell afterwards.

Anna spoke to Stacy:

"This is their punishment. they are transformed - as permanently as you were. They will live out long lives - and oak trees live a very long time - as part of this forest. Here, they will be useful to the world around them, which is more than they would have been rotting in a cell somewhere. Maria and I have cast the storngest protective spell we can. They will be safe from fire, disease, insects, even human meddling."

"Are they still - human - inside, I mean?" asked Stacy.

"Yes", said Anna, "they still have their human 'minds'. They are aware of who they were, and of what they have become. They can even 'talk' to one another, psychically. Listen."

Stacy could now hear her parents' voices. they were lamenting their fate, and berating one another for bringing them to it.

"You could even speak to them, if you wish."

"Maybe someday", said Stacy, "but not now, pelase."

"As you wish." Anna gestured, and the voices faded.

They drove back to Stacy's house.

"What will happen to ypur home with your family gone?" asked Anna.

"Dunno", said Stacy. "As far as I know, I was my parents' sole heir. They weren't much for extended family. I think I have some second cousins on my mother's side, but I've never met them."

Anna thought about it for a moment.

"Let's go through the house, and see whether there's anything you want to keep."

In the end, there wasn't much, mostly a few keepsakes and heirlooms. A few other things, Maria and Anna kept for their own uses, with Stacy's gladly-given permission. Anna and Maria magically transported the items back to their home.

"Time for one last big spell."

Anna led Maria in an incantation. Her home vanished, and the lots of the neighbors on either side extended to divide what had been her parents' land right down the middle. It was as though the house had never stood there.

"Won't this increase the nieghbors' property taxes, enlarging their lots like that?" asked Maria.

"I included an element in the spell to adjust their assessments", said Anna. She addressed Stacy. In addition to making it as though the house never existed, we've removed all memory and record of you and your parents, except for what we know, of course. I know it's hard to think that you're forgotten, but it's better than having people going around looking for you. Whoo, I am beat."

The three drove back to the Yoshino home. That night, Stacy slept in Maria's room again, but the next day, Anna magickally added a room onto the back of the house, and furnished it with the things Stacy had taken from her home.

They all rested for a week, but on the morning of the eighth day, Anna smiled amiably at the pair of them after breakfast, and said:

"Alright, Mighty Sorceress, it's time to step up your training so that you can learn to properly use those vast new powers of yours. Wipe that smirk off your beak, Parrot Girl, you're included in this, too."

Maria and Stacy looked at one another in resignation. Life was about to get interesting.
1353321112111121.title: "Yes."

13533211121111212.content:
Time sped by. Before Stacy knew it, a hundred years had gone by, until now it was 2114. Her life as a human was a long-distant memory. She and Maria had spent twenty years training with Anna, before the latter had declared that there was nothing more that she could teach her daughter. After that, Vieno had consented to take Maria on as an apprentice, which lasted another twenty years. Initially, this had seemed like an impossibly long time to train. but as Maria said, when one may reasonably anticipate liivng for millennia, twenty years was hardly long at all. Eventually, Vieno, too, professed herself satisfied that Maria had learned what she could teach her. Maria and Stacy had then spent another ten years traveling the world, meeting other witches and other magickal being, leanring what they could from them, before returning home to set up a household of their own.

During this time, Maria had, as she had predicted, remained single, although she had from time to time, had "liaisons" with various mundane men and male witches ("Never call them 'warlocks'", Maria had said.). Witches tended not to marry much, anyway, Maria had explained. Their long lifespans, made "happily ever after" somewhat more problematical than it was for mundanes, who at most only had to put up with one another for a century if they lived that long. There were a few witch couples that had been "together" for centuries, but they were a rarity. If a child resulted from a witch "liaison", then custody of said child was something that was typically worked out by the parents, with input from their families, if needed.

Witches were strictly forbidden to marry mundanes - this grew out of the rule that the very existence of witches was to be kept secret from mundanes except under special circumstances. Had Amanda lives much longer, she would almost certainly have found herself in trouble for her dealings with Stacy's parents. Stacy was still a little vague on how this rule was enforced, but she knew it was. It occasionally led to some sad situations, but the rule was generally pretty well followed. As long as he or she didn't break this rule, a witch could have a long-time association with a mundane if they were careful, but this practice was discouraged.

If a child resulted from a witch/mundane relationship, its fate would depend on its mother. The child of a witch father and a mundane mother was wholly a mundane and would always be in the mother's care. If the mother died in childbirth, the child would be given into the custody of its nearest mundane relatives. If none such were available, they were placed with appropriate mundane authorities. It was forbidden for the witch father to take custody of the child. This seemed harsh to Stacy, but the law was generally obeyed.


On the other hand, if the mother was a witch, and the father was a mundane, the child would be wholly a witch. (There was no such thing as a witch/mundane "hybrid".) The mother would have custody of the child as a matter of course. Maria had never heard of a witch dying in childbirth, but she assumed that if such a thing happened, that the child would be placed with an appropriate witch. In this case, the mother was expected to end the liaison and to never inform the father of the child's existence, as it was felt impossible to conceal the child's magickal nature from a parent. This meant that alot of witch mothers were effectively single mothers.

Frequently, a female witch who wanted a child (and for whom there was no willing male witch available) would carefully vet prospective male mundanes, selecting one possessing desired appropriate characteristics to father her child. (Non-magickal characteristics were passed along largely according to mundane laws of genetics.) Maria had been the result of such a choice by Anna. Witches were fertile for a long time, and often spread their families over centuries. Stacy had been surprised to learn that Maria had three older sisters and an older brother: Sazae (born in 1573), Takashi (born in 1662), Emiko (born in 1808), and Joanna (born in 1915). She also now had a kid sister, Elizabeth, born in 2034, some twenty years after Stacy's transformation. The older siblings didn't come around much. By 2114, Stacy had only met Sazae, Joanna and, of course, Elizabeth. Maria herself had met all of her sisters but had never met Takashi. It wasn't that the other siblings were estranged, simply that for witches, absences of decades or even centuries were not uncommon.

Some witches carefully planned who would father their children, and when. Maria, on the other hand, had a careless moment with a handsome young fellow during a visit to Hokkaido in early 2098, which resulted in the Christmas Eve birth of her daughter Jennifer. Despite her lack of preparation, her pregnancy had gone well, with a great deal of help from Stacy, Anna and Elizabeth.

Ten years later, in 2108, Anna had another daughter, Charlotte, providing Jennifer with an aunt that was younger than her.

As for Stacy, she had set aside romance, emotional or physical, from her life. She certainly had no interest in mundane parrots, and she had never encountered a magickal one. She devoted herself to helping Maria and her new "niece".

One day, when Jennifer was sixteen, and Charlotte was six, all of Anna's daughters gathered at her house. Sazae, Emiko, Joanna, Maria, Elizabeth and Charlotte were all there. Only Takashi was absent - he was said to be off in some other realm or other. Because of the nature of witchly aging, Anna and her daughters all looked as though they were within a few years of age of one another. Jennifer also was present, playing with Charlotte while her grandmother and her other aunts caught up with one another's doings. Emiko was fascinated to meet Stacy. Of all of Anna's daughters, only Maria had seen fit to take on a fa'iit't'aarah.

After a pleasant lunch, Anna called over Jennifer and Charlotte.

"Jennifer, I have to ask you a favor - as you know, the reason we're all gathered here today is because we have to go to the Grand Convocation, and you two are both too young to go. Don't feel bad, it's just going to be a few hours of witches b.s.-ing one another about what great spells they've invented. You'll both be more than old enough by the time they have the next one, and then you'll find out for yourselves. Anyway, Jennifer, would you mind babysitting your Aunt Charlotte for the afternoon? We should be back by nightfall."

"Sure thing, Grandma."

"And you, Charlotte, will you behave for Jennifer?"

"Yes, Mama."

"Good. Jennifer, you know where everything is here, and if there's an emergency, just contact me using that magic cellphone your mother gave you. Feel free to hang out here, or to go to the Park."

With that, Anna and the others took their leave.

Jennifer smiled. All her life she'd heard the story of what had happened to Stacy, and now she was the "mystical babysitter". She turned to her little aunt, and said:

"So, Auntie, do you want to hang out here, or do you want to go to the Park?"

Charlotte smiled at her niece, and said:

Stacy felt herself drifting off to sleep as Amanda left the room. Smirking, Amanda went downstairs, where she picked up the phone and called Stacy's best friend, Miranda Alvarez.

Using Stacy's voice, she said, "Hey, Randi, whatcha doin'?"

"Not much", said Miranda. "What's up with you? How's your babysitter?"

"She's fine", said Amanda, still using Stacy's voice, "She's actually cooler than I thought she would be. She said she didn't care what I did as long as I didn't do anything that got back to my parents. anyway, why don't you come over and hang out?"

"Sure", said Miranda. "Can I bring Abby, too? I was thinking of calling her, anyway." Abigail Nomura was a mutual friend of theirs.

"Sure", said Amanda."The more the merrier."

Miranda and Abigail arrived at Stacy's house about half an hour later. Miranda rang the doorbell, when they received no answer after a few minutes, Miranda tried the doorknob. It was open, so they wen t in. They looked around, but saw no one.

"Stacy? You here?", said Miranda. "You left the door unlocked again!"


"Hey, guys!", came Stacy's voice from upstairs. "Come on up!"

Locking the door behind them, Randi and Abby went upstairs. When they reached the top of the stairs, Amanda, who was hiding out of sight, smiled as she watched them. Her eyes glowed bright red.

Randi's legs seemed to go out from under her. "What the heck?", she said.

Abby looked at her friend in surprise."Randi, are you alrah- Ah gah? wah gah bah bha bah?" she put her hand to he throat.

Randi looked up at her friend. "What did you say?", she said.

"Ah gah gah-gah wahhhh!", wailed Abby. try as she might, she could no longer make her mouth form words.

Randi tried to get to her feet, but found that she could no longer stand upright. Abby continued babbling incoherently.

"Abby, help me up, would you?", said Randi. Abby tried to help her friend, but found that she could no longer control her arms.

Interesting how the spell affects them both differently, thought Amanda, still watching from out of sight.

Frustrated, Randi said,"Hey, Stacy, give us a hand would you?"


When no response came, Randi began to be worried. What's going on here?

Accepting the inevitable, she crawled along on all fours in the direction of Stacy's room. Abby followed her, still babbling non-stop. As they moved down the hall, their clothing disappeared, replaced by diapers.

"What the Hell?", said Randi. Now she was really scared. Whatever was going on here wasn't natural. "Stacy? Stacy? Where are you?"

"Ah bah gah!", added Abby.

As they moved down the hall, Randi noticed that everything seemed to be getting bigger around her and Abby. she looked at Abby, and gaped. Abby was not only getting smaller, she was getting younger. She looked about eleven years old! Randi looked at her own body. she was getting younger, too!
